AddInstanceGroups.documentation: AddInstanceGroups adds an instance group to a running cluster.

AddJobFlowSteps.documentation:
AddJobFlowSteps adds new steps to a running job flow. A maximum of 256 steps are allowed in each job flow. 

 If your job flow is long-running (such as a Hive data warehouse) or complex, you may require more than 256 steps to process your data. You can bypass the 256-step limitation in various ways, including using the SSH shell to connect to the master node and submitting queries directly to the software running on the master node, such as Hive and Hadoop. For more information on how to do this, go to `Add More than 256 Steps to a Job Flow <http://docs.aws.amazon.com/ElasticMapReduce/latest/DeveloperGuide/AddMoreThan256Steps.html>`_ in the *Amazon Elastic MapReduce Developer's Guide*.

  A step specifies the location of a JAR file stored either on the master node of the job flow or in Amazon S3. Each step is performed by the main function of the main class of the JAR file. The main class can be specified either in the manifest of the JAR or by using the MainFunction parameter of the step. 

  Elastic MapReduce executes each step in the order listed. For a step to be considered complete, the main function must exit with a zero exit code and all Hadoop jobs started while the step was running must have completed and run successfully. 

  You can only add steps to a job flow that is in one of the following states: STARTING, BOOTSTRAPPING, RUNNING, or WAITING.

AddTags.documentation: Adds tags to an Amazon EMR resource. Tags make it easier to associate clusters in various ways, such as grouping clusters to track your Amazon EMR resource allocation costs. For more information, see `Tagging Amazon EMR Resources <http://docs.aws.amazon.com/ElasticMapReduce/latest/DeveloperGuide/emr-plan-tags.html>`_.

DescribeCluster.documentation: Provides cluster-level details including status, hardware and software configuration, VPC settings, and so on. For information about the cluster steps, see ListSteps.

DescribeJobFlows.documentation:
This API is deprecated and will eventually be removed. We recommend you use ListClusters, DescribeCluster, ListSteps, ListInstanceGroups and ListBootstrapActions instead.

  DescribeJobFlows returns a list of job flows that match all of the supplied parameters. The parameters can include a list of job flow IDs, job flow states, and restrictions on job flow creation date and time.

  Regardless of supplied parameters, only job flows created within the last two months are returned.

  If no parameters are supplied, then job flows matching either of the following criteria are returned:

 

  * Job flows created and completed in the last two weeks
  *  Job flows created within the last two months that are in one of the following states: ``RUNNING``, ``WAITING``, ``SHUTTING_DOWN``, ``STARTING`` 
 
  Amazon Elastic MapReduce can return a maximum of 512 job flow descriptions.

DescribeStep.documentation: Provides more detail about the cluster step.

ListBootstrapActions.documentation: Provides information about the bootstrap actions associated with a cluster.

ListClusters.documentation: Provides the status of all clusters visible to this AWS account. Allows you to filter the list of clusters based on certain criteria; for example, filtering by cluster creation date and time or by status. This call returns a maximum of 50 clusters per call, but returns a marker to track the paging of the cluster list across multiple ListClusters calls.

ListInstanceGroups.documentation: Provides all available details about the instance groups in a cluster.

ListInstances.documentation: Provides information about the cluster instances that Amazon EMR provisions on behalf of a user when it creates the cluster. For example, this operation indicates when the EC2 instances reach the Ready state, when instances become available to Amazon EMR to use for jobs, and the IP addresses for cluster instances, etc.

ListSteps.documentation: Provides a list of steps for the cluster.

ModifyInstanceGroups.documentation: ModifyInstanceGroups modifies the number of nodes and configuration settings of an instance group. The input parameters include the new target instance count for the group and the instance group ID. The call will either succeed or fail atomically.

RemoveTags.documentation:
Removes tags from an Amazon EMR resource. Tags make it easier to associate clusters in various ways, such as grouping clusters to track your Amazon EMR resource allocation costs. For more information, see `Tagging Amazon EMR Resources <http://docs.aws.amazon.com/ElasticMapReduce/latest/DeveloperGuide/emr-plan-tags.html>`_. 

 The following example removes the stack tag with value Prod from a cluster:

RunJobFlow.documentation:
RunJobFlow creates and starts running a new job flow. The job flow will run the steps specified. Once the job flow completes, the cluster is stopped and the HDFS partition is lost. To prevent loss of data, configure the last step of the job flow to store results in Amazon S3. If the JobFlowInstancesConfig ``KeepJobFlowAliveWhenNoSteps`` parameter is set to ``TRUE``, the job flow will transition to the WAITING state rather than shutting down once the steps have completed. 

 For additional protection, you can set the JobFlowInstancesConfig ``TerminationProtected`` parameter to ``TRUE`` to lock the job flow and prevent it from being terminated by API call, user intervention, or in the event of a job flow error.

 A maximum of 256 steps are allowed in each job flow.

 If your job flow is long-running (such as a Hive data warehouse) or complex, you may require more than 256 steps to process your data. You can bypass the 256-step limitation in various ways, including using the SSH shell to connect to the master node and submitting queries directly to the software running on the master node, such as Hive and Hadoop. For more information on how to do this, go to `Add More than 256 Steps to a Job Flow <http://docs.aws.amazon.com/ElasticMapReduce/latest/DeveloperGuide/AddMoreThan256Steps.html>`_ in the *Amazon Elastic MapReduce Developer's Guide*.

 For long running job flows, we recommend that you periodically store your results.

SetTerminationProtection.documentation:
SetTerminationProtection locks a job flow so the Amazon EC2 instances in the cluster cannot be terminated by user intervention, an API call, or in the event of a job-flow error. The cluster still terminates upon successful completion of the job flow. Calling SetTerminationProtection on a job flow is analogous to calling the Amazon EC2 DisableAPITermination API on all of the EC2 instances in a cluster.

  SetTerminationProtection is used to prevent accidental termination of a job flow and to ensure that in the event of an error, the instances will persist so you can recover any data stored in their ephemeral instance storage.

  To terminate a job flow that has been locked by setting SetTerminationProtection to ``true``, you must first unlock the job flow by a subsequent call to SetTerminationProtection in which you set the value to ``false``. 

  For more information, go to `Protecting a Job Flow from Termination <http://docs.aws.amazon.com/ElasticMapReduce/latest/DeveloperGuide/UsingEMR_TerminationProtection.html>`_ in the *Amazon Elastic MapReduce Developer's Guide.*

SetVisibleToAllUsers.documentation: Sets whether all AWS Identity and Access Management (IAM) users under your account can access the specified job flows. This action works on running job flows. You can also set the visibility of a job flow when you launch it using the ``VisibleToAllUsers`` parameter of RunJobFlow. The SetVisibleToAllUsers action can be called only by an IAM user who created the job flow or the AWS account that owns the job flow.

TerminateJobFlows.documentation:
TerminateJobFlows shuts a list of job flows down. When a job flow is shut down, any step not yet completed is canceled and the EC2 instances on which the job flow is running are stopped. Any log files not already saved are uploaded to Amazon S3 if a LogUri was specified when the job flow was created. 

  The maximum number of JobFlows allowed is 10. The call to TerminateJobFlows is asynchronous. Depending on the configuration of the job flow, it may take up to 5-20 minutes for the job flow to completely terminate and release allocated resources, such as Amazon EC2 instances.

members.name: InstanceGroups
members.documentation: Instance Groups to add.

members.name: JobFlowId
members.documentation: Job flow in which to add the instance groups.

members.name: JobFlowId
members.documentation: The job flow ID in which the instance groups are added.

members.name: InstanceGroupIds
members.documentation: Instance group IDs of the newly created instance groups.

AddJobFlowStepsInput.documentation: The input argument to the AddJobFlowSteps operation.

members.name: JobFlowId
members.documentation: A string that uniquely identifies the job flow. This identifier is returned by RunJobFlow and can also be obtained from ListClusters.

members.name: Steps
members.documentation: A list of StepConfig to be executed by the job flow.

AddJobFlowStepsOutput.documentation: The output for the AddJobFlowSteps operation.

members.name: StepIds
members.documentation: The identifiers of the list of steps added to the job flow.

AddTagsInput.documentation: This input identifies a cluster and a list of tags to attach.

members.name: ResourceId
members.documentation: The Amazon EMR resource identifier to which tags will be added. This value must be a cluster identifier.

members.name: Tags
members.documentation: A list of tags to associate with a cluster and propagate to Amazon EC2 instances. Tags are user-defined key/value pairs that consist of a required key string with a maximum of 128 characters, and an optional value string with a maximum of 256 characters.

AddTagsOutput.documentation: This output indicates the result of adding tags to a resource.

Application.documentation:
An application is any Amazon or third-party software that you can add to the cluster. This structure contains a list of strings that indicates the software to use with the cluster and accepts a user argument list. Amazon EMR accepts and forwards the argument list to the corresponding installation script as bootstrap action argument. For more information, see `Launch a Job Flow on the MapR Distribution for Hadoop <http://docs.aws.amazon.com/ElasticMapReduce/latest/DeveloperGuide/emr-mapr.html>`_. Currently supported values are:

 

  * "mapr-m3" - launch the job flow using MapR M3 Edition.
  * "mapr-m5" - launch the job flow using MapR M5 Edition.
  * "mapr" with the user arguments specifying "--edition,m3" or "--edition,m5" - launch the job flow using MapR M3 or M5 Edition, respectively.
 
 In Amazon EMR releases 4.0 and greater, the only accepted parameter is the application name. To pass arguments to applications, you supply a configuration for each application.

members.name: Name
members.documentation: The name of the application.

members.name: Version
members.documentation: The version of the application.

members.name: Args
members.documentation: Arguments for Amazon EMR to pass to the application.

members.name: AdditionalInfo
members.documentation: This option is for advanced users only. This is meta information about third-party applications that third-party vendors use for testing purposes.

members.name: Name
members.documentation: The name of the bootstrap action.

members.name: ScriptBootstrapAction
members.documentation: The script run by the bootstrap action.

BootstrapActionDetail.documentation: Reports the configuration of a bootstrap action in a job flow.

members.name: BootstrapActionConfig
members.documentation: A description of the bootstrap action.

Cluster.documentation: The detailed description of the cluster.

members.name: Id
members.documentation: The unique identifier for the cluster.

members.name: Name
members.documentation: The name of the cluster.

members.name: Status
members.documentation: The current status details about the cluster.

members.name: LogUri
members.documentation: The path to the Amazon S3 location where logs for this cluster are stored.

members.name: RequestedAmiVersion
members.documentation: The AMI version requested for this cluster.

members.name: RunningAmiVersion
members.documentation: The AMI version running on this cluster.

members.name: ReleaseLabel
members.documentation: The release label for the Amazon EMR release. For Amazon EMR 3.x and 2.x AMIs, use amiVersion instead instead of ReleaseLabel.

members.name: AutoTerminate
members.documentation: Specifies whether the cluster should terminate after completing all steps.

members.name: TerminationProtected
members.documentation: Indicates whether Amazon EMR will lock the cluster to prevent the EC2 instances from being terminated by an API call or user intervention, or in the event of a cluster error.

members.name: VisibleToAllUsers
members.documentation: Indicates whether the job flow is visible to all IAM users of the AWS account associated with the job flow. If this value is set to true, all IAM users of that AWS account can view and manage the job flow if they have the proper policy permissions set. If this value is false, only the IAM user that created the cluster can view and manage it. This value can be changed using the SetVisibleToAllUsers action.

members.name: Applications
members.documentation: The applications installed on this cluster.

members.name: Tags
members.documentation: A list of tags associated with a cluster.

members.name: ServiceRole
members.documentation: The IAM role that will be assumed by the Amazon EMR service to access AWS resources on your behalf.

members.name: NormalizedInstanceHours
members.documentation: An approximation of the cost of the job flow, represented in m1.small/hours. This value is incremented one time for every hour an m1.small instance runs. Larger instances are weighted more, so an EC2 instance that is roughly four times more expensive would result in the normalized instance hours being incremented by four. This result is only an approximation and does not reflect the actual billing rate.

members.name: MasterPublicDnsName
members.documentation: The public DNS name of the master EC2 instance.

members.name: Configurations
members.documentation:
Amazon EMR releases 4.x or later.

The list of Configurations supplied to the EMR cluster.

ClusterStateChangeReason.documentation: The reason that the cluster changed to its current state.

members.name: Code
members.documentation: The programmatic code for the state change reason.

members.name: Message
members.documentation: The descriptive message for the state change reason.

ClusterStatus.documentation: The detailed status of the cluster.

members.name: State
members.documentation: The current state of the cluster.

members.name: StateChangeReason
members.documentation: The reason for the cluster status change.

members.name: Timeline
members.documentation: A timeline that represents the status of a cluster over the lifetime of the cluster.

ClusterSummary.documentation: The summary description of the cluster.

members.name: Id
members.documentation: The unique identifier for the cluster.

members.name: Name
members.documentation: The name of the cluster.

members.name: Status
members.documentation: The details about the current status of the cluster.

members.name: NormalizedInstanceHours
members.documentation: An approximation of the cost of the job flow, represented in m1.small/hours. This value is incremented one time for every hour an m1.small instance runs. Larger instances are weighted more, so an EC2 instance that is roughly four times more expensive would result in the normalized instance hours being incremented by four. This result is only an approximation and does not reflect the actual billing rate.

ClusterTimeline.documentation: Represents the timeline of the cluster's lifecycle.

members.name: CreationDateTime
members.documentation: The creation date and time of the cluster.

members.name: ReadyDateTime
members.documentation: The date and time when the cluster was ready to execute steps.

members.name: EndDateTime
members.documentation: The date and time when the cluster was terminated.

Command.documentation: An entity describing an executable that runs on a cluster.

members.name: Name
members.documentation: The name of the command.

members.name: ScriptPath
members.documentation: The Amazon S3 location of the command script.

members.name: Args
members.documentation: Arguments for Amazon EMR to pass to the command for execution.

Configuration.documentation:
Amazon EMR releases 4.x or later.

 Specifies a hardware and software configuration of the EMR cluster. This includes configurations for applications and software bundled with Amazon EMR. The Configuration object is a JSON object which is defined by a classification and a set of properties. Configurations can be nested, so a configuration may have its own Configuration objects listed.

members.name: Classification
members.documentation: The classification of a configuration. For more information see, Amazon EMR Configurations.

members.name: Configurations
members.documentation: A list of configurations you apply to this configuration object.

members.name: Properties
members.documentation: A set of properties supplied to the Configuration object.

DescribeClusterInput.documentation: This input determines which cluster to describe.

members.name: ClusterId
members.documentation: The identifier of the cluster to describe.

DescribeClusterOutput.documentation: This output contains the description of the cluster.

members.name: Cluster
members.documentation: This output contains the details for the requested cluster.

DescribeJobFlowsInput.documentation: The input for the DescribeJobFlows operation.

members.name: CreatedAfter
members.documentation: Return only job flows created after this date and time.

members.name: CreatedBefore
members.documentation: Return only job flows created before this date and time.

members.name: JobFlowIds
members.documentation: Return only job flows whose job flow ID is contained in this list.

members.name: JobFlowStates
members.documentation: Return only job flows whose state is contained in this list.

DescribeJobFlowsOutput.documentation: The output for the DescribeJobFlows operation.

members.name: JobFlows
members.documentation: A list of job flows matching the parameters supplied.

DescribeStepInput.documentation: This input determines which step to describe.

members.name: ClusterId
members.documentation: The identifier of the cluster with steps to describe.

members.name: StepId
members.documentation: The identifier of the step to describe.

DescribeStepOutput.documentation: This output contains the description of the cluster step.

members.name: Step
members.documentation: The step details for the requested step identifier.

Ec2InstanceAttributes.documentation: Provides information about the EC2 instances in a cluster grouped by category. For example, key name, subnet ID, IAM instance profile, and so on.

members.name: Ec2KeyName
members.documentation: The name of the Amazon EC2 key pair to use when connecting with SSH into the master node as a user named "hadoop".

members.name: Ec2SubnetId
members.documentation:
To launch the job flow in Amazon VPC, set this parameter to the identifier of the Amazon VPC subnet where you want the job flow to launch. If you do not specify this value, the job flow is launched in the normal AWS cloud, outside of a VPC.

Amazon VPC currently does not support cluster compute quadruple extra large (cc1.4xlarge) instances. Thus, you cannot specify the cc1.4xlarge instance type for nodes of a job flow launched in a VPC.

members.name: Ec2AvailabilityZone
members.documentation: The Availability Zone in which the cluster will run.

members.name: IamInstanceProfile
members.documentation: The IAM role that was specified when the job flow was launched. The EC2 instances of the job flow assume this role.

members.name: EmrManagedMasterSecurityGroup
members.documentation: The identifier of the Amazon EC2 security group (managed by Amazon Elastic MapReduce) for the master node.

members.name: EmrManagedSlaveSecurityGroup
members.documentation: The identifier of the Amazon EC2 security group (managed by Amazon Elastic MapReduce) for the slave nodes.

members.name: AdditionalMasterSecurityGroups
members.documentation: A list of additional Amazon EC2 security group IDs for the master node.

members.name: AdditionalSlaveSecurityGroups
members.documentation: A list of additional Amazon EC2 security group IDs for the slave nodes.

HadoopJarStepConfig.documentation: A job flow step consisting of a JAR file whose main function will be executed. The main function submits a job for Hadoop to execute and waits for the job to finish or fail.

members.name: Properties
members.documentation: A list of Java properties that are set when the step runs. You can use these properties to pass key value pairs to your main function.

members.name: Jar
members.documentation: A path to a JAR file run during the step.

members.name: MainClass
members.documentation: The name of the main class in the specified Java file. If not specified, the JAR file should specify a Main-Class in its manifest file.

members.name: Args
members.documentation: A list of command line arguments passed to the JAR file's main function when executed.

HadoopStepConfig.documentation: A cluster step consisting of a JAR file whose main function will be executed. The main function submits a job for Hadoop to execute and waits for the job to finish or fail.

members.name: Jar
members.documentation: The path to the JAR file that runs during the step.

members.name: Properties
members.documentation: The list of Java properties that are set when the step runs. You can use these properties to pass key value pairs to your main function.

members.name: MainClass
members.documentation: The name of the main class in the specified Java file. If not specified, the JAR file should specify a main class in its manifest file.

members.name: Args
members.documentation: The list of command line arguments to pass to the JAR file's main function for execution.

Instance.documentation: Represents an EC2 instance provisioned as part of cluster.

members.name: Id
members.documentation: The unique identifier for the instance in Amazon EMR.

members.name: Ec2InstanceId
members.documentation: The unique identifier of the instance in Amazon EC2.

members.name: PublicDnsName
members.documentation: The public DNS name of the instance.

members.name: PublicIpAddress
members.documentation: The public IP address of the instance.

members.name: PrivateDnsName
members.documentation: The private DNS name of the instance.

members.name: PrivateIpAddress
members.documentation: The private IP address of the instance.

members.name: Status
members.documentation: The current status of the instance.

InstanceGroup.documentation: This entity represents an instance group, which is a group of instances that have common purpose. For example, CORE instance group is used for HDFS.

members.name: Id
members.documentation: The identifier of the instance group.

members.name: Name
members.documentation: The name of the instance group.

members.name: Market
members.documentation: The marketplace to provision instances for this group. Valid values are ON_DEMAND or SPOT.

members.name: InstanceGroupType
members.documentation: The type of the instance group. Valid values are MASTER, CORE or TASK.

members.name: BidPrice
members.documentation: The bid price for each EC2 instance in the instance group when launching nodes as Spot Instances, expressed in USD.

members.name: InstanceType
members.documentation: The EC2 instance type for all instances in the instance group.

members.name: RequestedInstanceCount
members.documentation: The target number of instances for the instance group.

members.name: RunningInstanceCount
members.documentation: The number of instances currently running in this instance group.

members.name: Status
members.documentation: The current status of the instance group.

members.name: Configurations
members.documentation:
Amazon EMR releases 4.x or later.

The list of configurations supplied for an EMR cluster instance group. You can specify a separate configuration for each instance group (master, core, and task).

InstanceGroupConfig.documentation: Configuration defining a new instance group.

members.name: Name
members.documentation: Friendly name given to the instance group.

members.name: Market
members.documentation: Market type of the Amazon EC2 instances used to create a cluster node.

members.name: InstanceRole
members.documentation: The role of the instance group in the cluster.

members.name: BidPrice
members.documentation: Bid price for each Amazon EC2 instance in the instance group when launching nodes as Spot Instances, expressed in USD.

members.name: InstanceType
members.documentation: The Amazon EC2 instance type for all instances in the instance group.

members.name: InstanceCount
members.documentation: Target number of instances for the instance group.

members.name: Configurations
members.documentation:
Amazon EMR releases 4.x or later.

The list of configurations supplied for an EMR cluster instance group. You can specify a separate configuration for each instance group (master, core, and task).

InstanceGroupDetail.documentation: Detailed information about an instance group.

members.name: InstanceGroupId
members.documentation: Unique identifier for the instance group.

members.name: Name
members.documentation: Friendly name for the instance group.

members.name: Market
members.documentation: Market type of the Amazon EC2 instances used to create a cluster node.

members.name: InstanceRole
members.documentation: Instance group role in the cluster

members.name: BidPrice
members.documentation: Bid price for EC2 Instances when launching nodes as Spot Instances, expressed in USD.

members.name: InstanceType
members.documentation: Amazon EC2 Instance type.

members.name: InstanceRequestCount
members.documentation: Target number of instances to run in the instance group.

members.name: InstanceRunningCount
members.documentation: Actual count of running instances.

members.name: State
members.documentation: State of instance group. The following values are deprecated: STARTING, TERMINATED, and FAILED.

members.name: LastStateChangeReason
members.documentation: Details regarding the state of the instance group.

members.name: CreationDateTime
members.documentation: The date/time the instance group was created.

members.name: StartDateTime
members.documentation: The date/time the instance group was started.

members.name: ReadyDateTime
members.documentation: The date/time the instance group was available to the cluster.

members.name: EndDateTime
members.documentation: The date/time the instance group was terminated.

members.name: InstanceGroupId
members.documentation: Unique ID of the instance group to expand or shrink.

members.name: InstanceCount
members.documentation: Target size for the instance group.

members.name: EC2InstanceIdsToTerminate
members.documentation: The EC2 InstanceIds to terminate. For advanced users only. Once you terminate the instances, the instance group will not return to its original requested size.

InstanceGroupStateChangeReason.documentation: The status change reason details for the instance group.

members.name: Code
members.documentation: The programmable code for the state change reason.

members.name: Message
members.documentation: The status change reason description.

InstanceGroupStatus.documentation: The details of the instance group status.

members.name: State
members.documentation: The current state of the instance group.

members.name: StateChangeReason
members.documentation: The status change reason details for the instance group.

members.name: Timeline
members.documentation: The timeline of the instance group status over time.

InstanceGroupTimeline.documentation: The timeline of the instance group lifecycle.

members.name: CreationDateTime
members.documentation: The creation date and time of the instance group.

members.name: ReadyDateTime
members.documentation: The date and time when the instance group became ready to perform tasks.

members.name: EndDateTime
members.documentation: The date and time when the instance group terminated.

InstanceStateChangeReason.documentation: The details of the status change reason for the instance.

members.name: Code
members.documentation: The programmable code for the state change reason.

members.name: Message
members.documentation: The status change reason description.

members.name: State
members.documentation: The current state of the instance.

members.name: StateChangeReason
members.documentation: The details of the status change reason for the instance.

members.name: Timeline
members.documentation: The timeline of the instance status over time.

InstanceTimeline.documentation: The timeline of the instance lifecycle.

members.name: CreationDateTime
members.documentation: The creation date and time of the instance.

members.name: ReadyDateTime
members.documentation: The date and time when the instance was ready to perform tasks.

members.name: EndDateTime
members.documentation: The date and time when the instance was terminated.

InternalServerError.documentation: Indicates that an error occurred while processing the request and that the request was not completed.

InternalServerException.documentation: This exception occurs when there is an internal failure in the EMR service.

members.name: Message
members.documentation: The message associated with the exception.

InvalidRequestException.documentation: This exception occurs when there is something wrong with user input.

members.name: ErrorCode
members.documentation: The error code associated with the exception.

members.name: Message
members.documentation: The message associated with the exception.

JobFlowDetail.documentation: A description of a job flow.

members.name: JobFlowId
members.documentation: The job flow identifier.

members.name: Name
members.documentation: The name of the job flow.

members.name: LogUri
members.documentation: The location in Amazon S3 where log files for the job are stored.

members.name: AmiVersion
members.documentation: The version of the AMI used to initialize Amazon EC2 instances in the job flow. For a list of AMI versions currently supported by Amazon ElasticMapReduce, go to AMI Versions Supported in Elastic MapReduce in the Amazon Elastic MapReduce Developer Guide.

members.name: ExecutionStatusDetail
members.documentation: Describes the execution status of the job flow.

members.name: Instances
members.documentation: Describes the Amazon EC2 instances of the job flow.

members.name: Steps
members.documentation: A list of steps run by the job flow.

members.name: BootstrapActions
members.documentation: A list of the bootstrap actions run by the job flow.

members.name: SupportedProducts
members.documentation: A list of strings set by third party software when the job flow is launched. If you are not using third party software to manage the job flow this value is empty.

members.name: VisibleToAllUsers
members.documentation: Specifies whether the job flow is visible to all IAM users of the AWS account associated with the job flow. If this value is set to true, all IAM users of that AWS account can view and (if they have the proper policy permissions set) manage the job flow. If it is set to false, only the IAM user that created the job flow can view and manage it. This value can be changed using the SetVisibleToAllUsers action.

members.name: JobFlowRole
members.documentation: The IAM role that was specified when the job flow was launched. The EC2 instances of the job flow assume this role.

members.name: ServiceRole
members.documentation: The IAM role that will be assumed by the Amazon EMR service to access AWS resources on your behalf.

JobFlowExecutionState.documentation:
The type of instance. 

   A small instance

   A large instance

JobFlowExecutionStatusDetail.documentation: Describes the status of the job flow.

members.name: State
members.documentation: The state of the job flow.

members.name: CreationDateTime
members.documentation: The creation date and time of the job flow.

members.name: StartDateTime
members.documentation: The start date and time of the job flow.

members.name: ReadyDateTime
members.documentation: The date and time when the job flow was ready to start running bootstrap actions.

members.name: EndDateTime
members.documentation: The completion date and time of the job flow.

members.name: LastStateChangeReason
members.documentation: Description of the job flow last changed state.

JobFlowInstancesConfig.documentation: A description of the Amazon EC2 instance running the job flow. A valid JobFlowInstancesConfig must contain at least InstanceGroups, which is the recommended configuration. However, a valid alternative is to have MasterInstanceType, SlaveInstanceType, and InstanceCount (all three must be present).

members.name: MasterInstanceType
members.documentation: The EC2 instance type of the master node.

members.name: SlaveInstanceType
members.documentation: The EC2 instance type of the slave nodes.

members.name: InstanceCount
members.documentation: The number of Amazon EC2 instances used to execute the job flow.

members.name: InstanceGroups
members.documentation: Configuration for the job flow's instance groups.

members.name: Ec2KeyName
members.documentation: The name of the Amazon EC2 key pair that can be used to ssh to the master node as the user called "hadoop."

members.name: Placement
members.documentation: The Availability Zone the job flow will run in.

members.name: KeepJobFlowAliveWhenNoSteps
members.documentation: Specifies whether the job flow should be kept alive after completing all steps.

members.name: TerminationProtected
members.documentation: Specifies whether to lock the job flow to prevent the Amazon EC2 instances from being terminated by API call, user intervention, or in the event of a job flow error.

members.name: HadoopVersion
members.documentation: The Hadoop version for the job flow. Valid inputs are "0.18" (deprecated), "0.20" (deprecated), "0.20.205" (deprecated), "1.0.3", "2.2.0", or "2.4.0". If you do not set this value, the default of 0.18 is used, unless the AmiVersion parameter is set in the RunJobFlow call, in which case the default version of Hadoop for that AMI version is used.

members.name: Ec2SubnetId
members.documentation:
To launch the job flow in Amazon Virtual Private Cloud (Amazon VPC), set this parameter to the identifier of the Amazon VPC subnet where you want the job flow to launch. If you do not specify this value, the job flow is launched in the normal Amazon Web Services cloud, outside of an Amazon VPC.

Amazon VPC currently does not support cluster compute quadruple extra large (cc1.4xlarge) instances. Thus you cannot specify the cc1.4xlarge instance type for nodes of a job flow launched in a Amazon VPC.

members.name: EmrManagedMasterSecurityGroup
members.documentation: The identifier of the Amazon EC2 security group (managed by Amazon ElasticMapReduce) for the master node.

members.name: EmrManagedSlaveSecurityGroup
members.documentation: The identifier of the Amazon EC2 security group (managed by Amazon ElasticMapReduce) for the slave nodes.

members.name: AdditionalMasterSecurityGroups
members.documentation: A list of additional Amazon EC2 security group IDs for the master node.

members.name: AdditionalSlaveSecurityGroups
members.documentation: A list of additional Amazon EC2 security group IDs for the slave nodes.

JobFlowInstancesDetail.documentation: Specify the type of Amazon EC2 instances to run the job flow on.

members.name: MasterInstanceType
members.documentation: The Amazon EC2 master node instance type.

members.name: MasterPublicDnsName
members.documentation: The DNS name of the master node.

members.name: MasterInstanceId
members.documentation: The Amazon EC2 instance identifier of the master node.

members.name: SlaveInstanceType
members.documentation: The Amazon EC2 slave node instance type.

members.name: InstanceCount
members.documentation: The number of Amazon EC2 instances in the cluster. If the value is 1, the same instance serves as both the master and slave node. If the value is greater than 1, one instance is the master node and all others are slave nodes.

members.name: InstanceGroups
members.documentation: Details about the job flow's instance groups.

members.name: NormalizedInstanceHours
members.documentation: An approximation of the cost of the job flow, represented in m1.small/hours. This value is incremented once for every hour an m1.small runs. Larger instances are weighted more, so an Amazon EC2 instance that is roughly four times more expensive would result in the normalized instance hours being incremented by four. This result is only an approximation and does not reflect the actual billing rate.

members.name: Ec2KeyName
members.documentation: The name of an Amazon EC2 key pair that can be used to ssh to the master node of job flow.

members.name: Ec2SubnetId
members.documentation: For job flows launched within Amazon Virtual Private Cloud, this value specifies the identifier of the subnet where the job flow was launched.

members.name: Placement
members.documentation: The Amazon EC2 Availability Zone for the job flow.

members.name: KeepJobFlowAliveWhenNoSteps
members.documentation: Specifies whether the job flow should terminate after completing all steps.

members.name: TerminationProtected
members.documentation: Specifies whether the Amazon EC2 instances in the cluster are protected from termination by API calls, user intervention, or in the event of a job flow error.

members.name: HadoopVersion
members.documentation: The Hadoop version for the job flow.

members.name: Key
members.documentation: The unique identifier of a key value pair.

members.name: Value
members.documentation: The value part of the identified key.

ListBootstrapActionsInput.documentation: This input determines which bootstrap actions to retrieve.

members.name: ClusterId
members.documentation: The cluster identifier for the bootstrap actions to list .

members.name: Marker
members.documentation: The pagination token that indicates the next set of results to retrieve .

ListBootstrapActionsOutput.documentation: This output contains the boostrap actions detail .

members.name: BootstrapActions
members.documentation: The bootstrap actions associated with the cluster .

members.name: Marker
members.documentation: The pagination token that indicates the next set of results to retrieve .

ListClustersInput.documentation: This input determines how the ListClusters action filters the list of clusters that it returns.

members.name: CreatedAfter
members.documentation: The creation date and time beginning value filter for listing clusters .

members.name: CreatedBefore
members.documentation: The creation date and time end value filter for listing clusters .

members.name: ClusterStates
members.documentation: The cluster state filters to apply when listing clusters.

members.name: Marker
members.documentation: The pagination token that indicates the next set of results to retrieve.

ListClustersOutput.documentation: This contains a ClusterSummaryList with the cluster details; for example, the cluster IDs, names, and status.

members.name: Clusters
members.documentation: The list of clusters for the account based on the given filters.

members.name: Marker
members.documentation: The pagination token that indicates the next set of results to retrieve.

ListInstanceGroupsInput.documentation: This input determines which instance groups to retrieve.

members.name: ClusterId
members.documentation: The identifier of the cluster for which to list the instance groups.

members.name: Marker
members.documentation: The pagination token that indicates the next set of results to retrieve.

ListInstanceGroupsOutput.documentation: This input determines which instance groups to retrieve.

members.name: InstanceGroups
members.documentation: The list of instance groups for the cluster and given filters.

members.name: Marker
members.documentation: The pagination token that indicates the next set of results to retrieve.

ListInstancesInput.documentation: This input determines which instances to list.

members.name: ClusterId
members.documentation: The identifier of the cluster for which to list the instances.

members.name: InstanceGroupId
members.documentation: The identifier of the instance group for which to list the instances.

members.name: InstanceGroupTypes
members.documentation: The type of instance group for which to list the instances.

members.name: Marker
members.documentation: The pagination token that indicates the next set of results to retrieve.

ListInstancesOutput.documentation: This output contains the list of instances.

members.name: Instances
members.documentation: The list of instances for the cluster and given filters.

members.name: Marker
members.documentation: The pagination token that indicates the next set of results to retrieve.

ListStepsInput.documentation: This input determines which steps to list.

members.name: ClusterId
members.documentation: The identifier of the cluster for which to list the steps.

members.name: StepStates
members.documentation: The filter to limit the step list based on certain states.

members.name: StepIds
members.documentation: The filter to limit the step list based on the identifier of the steps.

members.name: Marker
members.documentation: The pagination token that indicates the next set of results to retrieve.

ListStepsOutput.documentation: This output contains the list of steps.

members.name: Steps
members.documentation: The filtered list of steps for the cluster.

members.name: Marker
members.documentation: The pagination token that indicates the next set of results to retrieve.

ModifyInstanceGroupsInput.documentation: Change the size of some instance groups.

members.name: InstanceGroups
members.documentation: Instance groups to change.

PlacementType.documentation: The Amazon EC2 location for the job flow.

members.name: AvailabilityZone
members.documentation: The Amazon EC2 Availability Zone for the job flow.

RemoveTagsInput.documentation: This input identifies a cluster and a list of tags to remove.

members.name: ResourceId
members.documentation: The Amazon EMR resource identifier from which tags will be removed. This value must be a cluster identifier.

members.name: TagKeys
members.documentation: A list of tag keys to remove from a resource.

RemoveTagsOutput.documentation: This output indicates the result of removing tags from a resource.

members.name: Name
members.documentation: The name of the job flow.

members.name: LogUri
members.documentation: The location in Amazon S3 to write the log files of the job flow. If a value is not provided, logs are not created.

members.name: AdditionalInfo
members.documentation: A JSON string for selecting additional features.

members.name: AmiVersion
members.documentation:
For Amazon EMR releases 3.x and 2.x. For Amazon EMR releases 4.x and greater, use ReleaseLabel.

The version of the Amazon Machine Image (AMI) to use when launching Amazon EC2 instances in the job flow. The following values are valid:

  • The version number of the AMI to use, for example, "2.0."

If the AMI supports multiple versions of Hadoop (for example, AMI 1.0 supports both Hadoop 0.18 and 0.20) you can use the JobFlowInstancesConfig HadoopVersion parameter to modify the version of Hadoop from the defaults shown above.

For details about the AMI versions currently supported by Amazon Elastic MapReduce, go to AMI Versions Supported in Elastic MapReduce in the Amazon Elastic MapReduce Developer's Guide.

members.name: ReleaseLabel
members.documentation:
Amazon EMR releases 4.x or later.

The release label for the Amazon EMR release. For Amazon EMR 3.x and 2.x AMIs, use amiVersion instead instead of ReleaseLabel.

members.name: Instances
members.documentation: A specification of the number and type of Amazon EC2 instances on which to run the job flow.

members.name: Steps
members.documentation: A list of steps to be executed by the job flow.

members.name: BootstrapActions
members.documentation: A list of bootstrap actions that will be run before Hadoop is started on the cluster nodes.

members.name: SupportedProducts
members.documentation:
For Amazon EMR releases 3.x and 2.x. For Amazon EMR releases 4.x and greater, use Applications.

A list of strings that indicates third-party software to use with the job flow. For more information, go to Use Third Party Applications with Amazon EMR. Currently supported values are:

  • "mapr-m3" - launch the job flow using MapR M3 Edition.
  • "mapr-m5" - launch the job flow using MapR M5 Edition.

members.name: NewSupportedProducts
members.documentation:
For Amazon EMR releases 3.x and 2.x. For Amazon EMR releases 4.x and greater, use Applications.

A list of strings that indicates third-party software to use with the job flow that accepts a user argument list. EMR accepts and forwards the argument list to the corresponding installation script as bootstrap action arguments. For more information, see Launch a Job Flow on the MapR Distribution for Hadoop. Currently supported values are:

  • "mapr-m3" - launch the cluster using MapR M3 Edition.
  • "mapr-m5" - launch the cluster using MapR M5 Edition.
  • "mapr" with the user arguments specifying "--edition,m3" or "--edition,m5" - launch the job flow using MapR M3 or M5 Edition respectively.
  • "mapr-m7" - launch the cluster using MapR M7 Edition.
  • "hunk" - launch the cluster with the Hunk Big Data Analtics Platform.
  • "hue"- launch the cluster with Hue installed.
  • "spark" - launch the cluster with Apache Spark installed.
  • "ganglia" - launch the cluster with the Ganglia Monitoring System installed.

members.name: Applications
members.documentation:
Amazon EMR releases 4.x or later.

A list of applications for the cluster. Valid values are: "Hadoop", "Hive", "Mahout", "Pig", and "Spark." They are case insensitive.

members.name: Configurations
members.documentation:
Amazon EMR releases 4.x or later.

The list of configurations supplied for the EMR cluster you are creating.

members.name: VisibleToAllUsers
members.documentation: Whether the job flow is visible to all IAM users of the AWS account associated with the job flow. If this value is set to true, all IAM users of that AWS account can view and (if they have the proper policy permissions set) manage the job flow. If it is set to false, only the IAM user that created the job flow can view and manage it.

members.name: JobFlowRole
members.documentation: An IAM role for the job flow. The EC2 instances of the job flow assume this role. The default role is EMRJobflowDefault. In order to use the default role, you must have already created it using the CLI.

members.name: ServiceRole
members.documentation: The IAM role that will be assumed by the Amazon EMR service to access AWS resources on your behalf.

members.name: Tags
members.documentation: A list of tags to associate with a cluster and propagate to Amazon EC2 instances.

RunJobFlowOutput.documentation: The result of the RunJobFlow operation.

members.name: JobFlowId
members.documentation: An unique identifier for the job flow.

ScriptBootstrapActionConfig.documentation: Configuration of the script to run during a bootstrap action.

members.name: Path
members.documentation: Location of the script to run during a bootstrap action. Can be either a location in Amazon S3 or on a local file system.

members.name: Args
members.documentation: A list of command line arguments to pass to the bootstrap action script.

SetTerminationProtectionInput.documentation: The input argument to the TerminationProtection operation.

members.name: JobFlowIds
members.documentation: A list of strings that uniquely identify the job flows to protect. This identifier is returned by RunJobFlow and can also be obtained from DescribeJobFlows .

members.name: TerminationProtected
members.documentation: A Boolean that indicates whether to protect the job flow and prevent the Amazon EC2 instances in the cluster from shutting down due to API calls, user intervention, or job-flow error.

SetVisibleToAllUsersInput.documentation: The input to the SetVisibleToAllUsers action.

members.name: JobFlowIds
members.documentation: Identifiers of the job flows to receive the new visibility setting.

members.name: VisibleToAllUsers
members.documentation: Whether the specified job flows are visible to all IAM users of the AWS account associated with the job flow. If this value is set to True, all IAM users of that AWS account can view and, if they have the proper IAM policy permissions set, manage the job flows. If it is set to False, only the IAM user that created a job flow can view and manage it.

Step.documentation: This represents a step in a cluster.

members.name: Id
members.documentation: The identifier of the cluster step.

members.name: Name
members.documentation: The name of the cluster step.

members.name: Config
members.documentation: The Hadoop job configuration of the cluster step.

members.name: ActionOnFailure
members.documentation: This specifies what action to take when the cluster step fails. Possible values are TERMINATE_CLUSTER, CANCEL_AND_WAIT, and CONTINUE.

members.name: Status
members.documentation: The current execution status details of the cluster step.

StepConfig.documentation: Specification of a job flow step.

members.name: Name
members.documentation: The name of the job flow step.

members.name: ActionOnFailure
members.documentation: The action to take if the job flow step fails.

members.name: HadoopJarStep
members.documentation: The JAR file used for the job flow step.

StepDetail.documentation: Combines the execution state and configuration of a step.

members.name: StepConfig
members.documentation: The step configuration.

members.name: ExecutionStatusDetail
members.documentation: The description of the step status.

StepExecutionStatusDetail.documentation: The execution state of a step.

members.name: State
members.documentation: The state of the job flow step.

members.name: CreationDateTime
members.documentation: The creation date and time of the step.

members.name: StartDateTime
members.documentation: The start date and time of the step.

members.name: EndDateTime
members.documentation: The completion date and time of the step.

members.name: LastStateChangeReason
members.documentation: A description of the step's current state.

StepStateChangeReason.documentation: The details of the step state change reason.

members.name: Code
members.documentation: The programmable code for the state change reason. Note: Currently, the service provides no code for the state change.

members.name: Message
members.documentation: The descriptive message for the state change reason.

StepStatus.documentation: The execution status details of the cluster step.

members.name: State
members.documentation: The execution state of the cluster step.

members.name: StateChangeReason
members.documentation: The reason for the step execution status change.

members.name: Timeline
members.documentation: The timeline of the cluster step status over time.

StepSummary.documentation: The summary of the cluster step.

members.name: Id
members.documentation: The identifier of the cluster step.

members.name: Name
members.documentation: The name of the cluster step.

members.name: Config
members.documentation: The Hadoop job configuration of the cluster step.

members.name: ActionOnFailure
members.documentation: This specifies what action to take when the cluster step fails. Possible values are TERMINATE_CLUSTER, CANCEL_AND_WAIT, and CONTINUE.

members.name: Status
members.documentation: The current execution status details of the cluster step.

StepTimeline.documentation: The timeline of the cluster step lifecycle.

members.name: CreationDateTime
members.documentation: The date and time when the cluster step was created.

members.name: StartDateTime
members.documentation: The date and time when the cluster step execution started.

members.name: EndDateTime
members.documentation: The date and time when the cluster step execution completed or failed.

SupportedProductConfig.documentation: The list of supported product configurations which allow user-supplied arguments. EMR accepts these arguments and forwards them to the corresponding installation script as bootstrap action arguments.

members.name: Name
members.documentation: The name of the product configuration.

members.name: Args
members.documentation: The list of user-supplied arguments.

Tag.documentation: A key/value pair containing user-defined metadata that you can associate with an Amazon EMR resource. Tags make it easier to associate clusters in various ways, such as grouping clu\ sters to track your Amazon EMR resource allocation costs. For more information, see `Tagging Amazon EMR Resources <http://docs.aws.amazon.com/ElasticMapReduce/latest/DeveloperGuide/emr-plan-tags.html>`_.

members.name: Key
members.documentation: A user-defined key, which is the minimum required information for a valid tag. For more information, see Tagging Amazon EMR Resources.

members.name: Value
members.documentation: A user-defined value, which is optional in a tag. For more information, see Tagging Amazon EMR Resources.

members.name: JobFlowIds
members.documentation: A list of job flows to be shutdown.
